title: Is Britain about to get a new women's WorldTour stage race?
content:
Joe Robinson
4 Jun 2021

RideLondon Classique set to be bumped to three days in May for 2022

The UCI has released its official women's WorldTour calendar for 2022 and there are a few things that caught our eye.

With 22 events, including a total of 10 stage races, the event that caught the headlines was that of the returning women's Tour de France. Set to be organised by ASO, it will be an eight-day race taking place one week after the men's race from 24th July to 31st July – replacing the exisiting one-day La Course.

But the eagle-eyed among you will have noticed the return of the RideLondon Classique, traditionally a one-day race in the UK that has historically offered the biggest prize pot in women's cycling. However, for 2022, it looks as if the RideLondon Classique will become a stage race with its dates pencilled in for 27th to 29th May, moving from its usual August slot.

This joins the Women's Tour, scheduled from 6th to 11th June, as the second women's WorldTour stage race to be taking place on British shores next year, making two more than there are men's WorldTour events.

Beyond racing in the UK, the Giro d'Italia – commonly known as the Giro Rosa – has returned to WorldTour status having been downgraded to 2.1 status for 2021. Running from 1st to 10th July, it will precede the inaugural women's Tour de France by two weeks.

The Ladies Tour of Norway has been renamed the Battle of the North, upping from four stages to six, while the Ceratizit Challenge by La Vuelta in September adds a fourth stage. There is also a return for the Postnord Vårgårda WestSweden road race and time-trial on 6th and 7th August.
